choices.text: Usually occurs after 3 years of starting amiodarone
High vascularity in color flow doppler ultrasound

questions.text: Not a feature of Amiodarone Induced Thyrotoxicosis type 1?
questions.solution: AIT type 1 usually occurs after 3 months of starting amiodarone

choices.text: It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern
The cause is a defect in the parathyroid hormone receptor.
Clinical symptoms first manifest in the third and fourth decades of life.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia?
questions.solution: FHH is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It results from a defect in serum calcium sensing by the parathyroid gland and renal tubule, causing inappropriate secretion of PTH and excessive renal reabsorption of calcium. The calcium-sensing receptor is sensitive to extracellular calcium concentration, suppressing PTH secretion and therefore resulting in negative-feedback regulation. Many different mutations in the calcium-sensing receptor have been described in patients with FHH. These mutations lower the ability of the sensor to bind calcium, resulting in excessive secretion of PTH and subsequent hypercalcemia. Urinary excretion of calcium is very low, with reabsorption more than 99%. The hypercalcemia is often detected in the first decade of life. This contrasts with primary hyperparathyroidism, which rarely occurs before age 10. Few clinical signs or symptoms are present in patients with FHH. These patients have excellent outcomes, and surgery or medical therapy is rarely necessary. Jansen’s disease refers to mutations in the PTH receptor.

questions.text: Which class of medications is the best choice for initial therapy of hypertension in diabetics?
questions.solution: ACE inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection in patients with diabetes (types 1 and 2). Patients with albuminuria and hypertension will certainly benefit from an ACE inhibitor. Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) are not indicated for the primary treatment of hypertension in diabetics (or, really, anyone else). Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are a reasonable alternative in the hypertensive patient with albuminuria if an ACE inhibitor is not tolerated. Vasodilators and calcium-channel blockers are not optimal choices in this patient although non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) are an option for renal protection in patients with worsening albuminuria especially in those who cannot tolerate an ACE inhibitor or ARB

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presented with facial puffiness and easy bruisability, while she was in her first trimester of pregnancy. On examination, she had facial plethora, lower abdominal purple stria, and proximal myopathy. A clinical suspicion of Cushing's syndrome was raised based on her signs and symptoms. Which one of the following is the most appropriate screening test for the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome in pregnancy?
questions.solution: The dexamethasone suppression test in pregnancy is associated with high rates of false positive results. The urinary free cortisol excretion remains normal in first trimester of pregnancy and increased up to 3-fold in the second and third trimesters. As a result, a UFC value of more than three times the normal limit is considered suggestive of a diagnosis of Cushing’s syndrome in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman was incidentally detected to have a 2-cm left adrenal gland mass while she underwent CT of the abdomen to investigate the cause of her pelvic pain and menstrual irregularities. Which one of the following is the most common cause of an incidentally- detected adrenal mass?
Which of the following agents is an anti-obesity medication as well ?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide, is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, and is almost identical to native GLP-1 except for an amino acid substitution and addition of a fatty acyl group (coupled with a gamma-glutamic acid spacer) that promote binding to albumin and plasma proteins and prolong its half-life. Higher doses of liraglutide than used for glucose-lowering effects have been approved for weight loss therapy for obesity.

Ref: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition page 2867

choices.text: All patients with incidentalomas should be screened for pheochromocytoma.
Fine-needle aspiration may distinguish between benign and malignant primary adrenal tumors
In patients with a history of malignancy, the likelihood the mass is a metastasis is ~50%.
The majority of adrenal incidentalomas are non- secretory.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding asymptomatic adrenal masses (incidentalomas) are true except
questions.solution: Incidental adrenal masses are often discovered during radiographic testing for another condition and are found in ~6% of adult subjects at autopsy. Fifty percent of patients with a history of malignancy and a newly discovered adrenal mass will actually have an adrenal metastasis. Fine-needle aspiration of a suspected metastatic malignancy will often be diagnostic. In the absence of a suspected non- adrenal malignancy, most adrenal incidentalomas are benign. Primary adrenal malignancies are uncommon (<0.01%), and fine-needle aspiration is not useful to distinguish between benign and malignant primary adrenal tumors. Although 90% of these masses are nonsecretory, patients with an incidentaloma should be screened for pheochromocytoma and hypercortisolism with plasma free metanephrines and an overnight dexamethasone suppression test, respectively. When radiographic features suggest a benign neoplasm (<3 cm), scanning should be repeated in 3–6 months. When masses are >6 cm, surgical removal (if more likely primary adrenal malignancy) or fine-needle aspiration (if more likely metastatic malignancy) is preferred.

choices.text: PTH receptors fail to respond to PTH
Serum calcium levels are high due to underlying bone pathology

questions.text: In pseudohypoparathyroidism:
questions.solution:
PSEUDOHYPOPARATHYROIDISM

  • Characterised by signs and symptoms of hypocalcemia in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects.
  • Hypocalcemia is due to a deficient response to PTH, which is probably restricted to the proximal renal tubules.
  • Hyperplasia of the parathyroids,a response to hormone resistant hypocalcemia,causes elevation of PTH levels.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP) is classified into four types.

  • PHP type Ia
  • PHP type Ib
  • Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism
  • PHP type II

The basis of this classification is:

  • Signs of ineffective PTH action (low calcium and high phosphate).
  • Low or normal urinary cAMP response to exogenous PTH.
  • Presence or absence of Alhright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO).
  • Assays to measure the concentration of the Gsα subunit of the adenylate cyclase enzyme.

choices.text: He has pituitary dysfunction with a pending central hypothyroidism
He has an isolated T3 hyperthyroidism
He is taking aspirin that interferes with the assay for free T4

questions.text: A 52-year-old male is being seen in your clinic for weight loss, tachycardia, and anxiety. You suspect hyperthyroidism and decide to check blood work. The patient has a low TSH suggestive of hyperthyroidism but has a normal free T4. The most likely explanation of this patient's symptoms and laboratory findings is:
questions.solution: Five percent of patients with hyperthyroidism have an isolated T3-toxicosis. Thus, if you suspect hyperthyroidism and the patient has a low TSH but a normal free T4, check a T3. Many drugs can interfere with thyroid-binding globulin and cause changes in the measurable amounts of total T4 (not free) and T3 in the serum. In most cases, the free T4 and free T3 (unbound thyroid hormones) are not affected by the changes in thyroid-binding globulin

choices.text: Increased risk of development of gall stones
Increased risk of pituitary tumour re-growth

questions.text: Which one of the clinical/biochemical changes is associated with pegvisomant therapy?
questions.solution: Pegvisomant is a genetically-modified analogue of GH, which acts as a highly selective GH receptor, which is useful for patients who are resistant or intolerant to somatostatin analogue therapy. It has a higher affinity for GH receptors site 1. It is used as a subcutaneous injection and the higher cost of therapy is a major limitation for its widespread use. It leads to the normalization of IGF-1 levels in more than 90% of patients with no adverse impact on glycaemic control or glucose tolerance as compared with the somatostatin analogues. It leads to an increase in GH levels through a loss of negative feedback effect. It does not lead to any shrinkage in tumour size.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the management of a 28 year old female diagnosed with prolactinoma who presented with amenorrhea and galactorrhea ?
questions.solution:
PROLACTINOMA

  • Most common pituitary hormone hypersecretion in both men and women is hyperprolactinemia.
  • Amenorrhea,galactorrhea,and infertility are the hallmarks of hyperprolactinemia in women.
  • In men with hyperprolactinemia,diminished libido,infertility,and visual loss (from optic nerve compression) are the usual presenting symptoms.
  • Most common cause of prolactin levels above 200 microgram/litre are prolactin secreting adenomas.
  • Microprolactinoma is <1cm in diameter and macroprolactinoma is >1cm in diameter.
  • Female:Male ratio for microprolactinomas is 20:1, whereas for macroprolactinoma, it is 1:1.

TREATMENT OF PROLACTINOMA

  • Asymptomatic microprolactinomas do not need treatment.
  • For symptomatic microprolactinomas, therapeutic goals are:
    -Control of hyperprolactinemia
    -Reduction of tumor size
    -Restoration of menses and fertility

-Resolution of galactorrhea

  • Medical management

Oral dopamine agonists (Cabergoline and Bromocriptine) are the mainstay of therapy for patients with micro or macroprolactinomas. Dopamine agonists suppress PRL secretion and synthesis as well as lactotrope cell proliferation.

CABERGOLINE

-Long-acting dopamine agonist with high D2 receptor affinity.
-Effectively suppresses prolactin for more than 14 days after a single oral dose and induces prolactinoma shrinkage in most patients.
-Achieves normoprolactinemia and shrinks ~70% of
macroprolactinomas and 80% of microprolactinomas.

-Bromocriptine is preferred over cabergoline in pregnancy.

Indications for surgical adenoma debulking:

-Dopamine resistance or intolerance.
-Presence of invasive macroadenoma with compromised vision that
fails to improve after drug treatment.

questions.text: Most common hormone pattern in non-thyroidal illness?
questions.solution:
The most common hormone pattern in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES), also called nonthyroidal illness (NTI), is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels (low T3 syndrome) with normal levels of T4 and TSH. The magnitude of the fall in T3 correlates with the severity of the illness.

Ref: Harrison’s principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition page 2709

choices.text: Blunting of cortisol response to dexamethasone suppression test
Loss of diurnal rhythm of cortisol secretion

questions.text: Which one of the following physiological changes is seen in ACTH- cortisol axis during normal pregnancy?
questions.solution: Normal physiological changes in pregnancy include weight gain; development of stria; an increase in levels of cortisol-binding globulin levels, resulting in increased cortisol levels; increased urinary free cortisol levels (up to 3-fold compared with the non-pregnant state during late third tri- mester) together with failure of dexamethasone to suppress cortisol response. There is no change in the circadian rhythm of cortisol secretion. Low or high dose dexamethasone suppression test and/ or CRH stimulation may be employed to distinguish physiological changes associated with pregnancy from Cushing’s syndrome. Reassuringly, Cushing’s syndrome is extremely uncommon in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions artificially raises the value of HbA1c ?
questions.solution: Iron deficiency may falsely elevate the HbA1c. Several other conditions can cause a falsely low HbA1c including sickle cell disease, malaria, acute blood loss, and hemolysis. In in all these conditions the bone marrow is pumping out new cells that have not been exposed to the elevated glucose levels. Conversely, iron deficiency and vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies may be associated with falsely high HbA1c levels, which is due to the proportion of older red cells (and therefore more glycosylated cells) in the blood being high compared to the normal individual. Chronic kidney disease may cause either a falsely elevated or falsely low HbA1c.

questions.text: Which one of the following DPP4 inhibitor is excreted unchanged in faeces and does not require any dose modification in renal disease?
questions.solution: Linagliptin is a DPP4 inhibitor that is predominantly excreted unchanged in faeces with metabolism of the drug playing a minor role in overall pharmacokinetics. It is a weak inhibitor of cytochrome P450. There is no dose adjustment required for linagliptin in renal failure patients.

questions.text: Alpha subunit of HCG is similar to all except
questions.solution:
Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

HCG is a glycoprotein encoded by single gene on chr. 6.

Secreted predominantly by syncitiotrophoblast but cytotrophoblast also contributes before 5 weeks

Molecular weight 36,000-40,000 dalton

Non specific alpha subunit (92 AA)

Specific Beta subunit (145 AA)

Alpha subunit is similar to TSH, FSH & LH

T1/2-36hours

Doubling time-1.4 to 2 days

Can be detected earliest by 8-9 days post conception

Maximum level is seen at 60-80 days (8 to 10 weeks) of pregnancy (100-200 IU/mL), then starts declining till 16 weeks and then plateaus

Concentration in maternal serum> amniotic fluid > fetal serum

HCG disappears from circulation within 2 weeks following delivery

Other Important Notes and recent Questions based on the chapter AND HIGHLY PROBABLE QUESTIONS

AFP is produced from fetal yolk sac, liver and GIT. It is the most abundant protein in serum of fetus.

AFP passes from urine of fetus into amniotic fluid and enters maternal serum by diffusion.

Therefore any defect in fetus wall will result in more of mixing in amniotic fluid and hence increased MSAFP

questions.text: A 60-year-old female who is the known case of chronic kidney disease for 10 years and is showing vitamin D deficiency in recent investigation panel, develop a painful skin lesion as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Calciphylaxis also refers calcific uremic arteriopathy is a rare manifestation
  • Painful violaceous skin lesions with associated ulceration, ischemia, necrosis and eschar formation
  • Characterised by micro vascular calcification, intimal proliferation, fibrosis and thrombotic occlusion of small subcutaneous vessels
  • Predominantly affects patients with end stage renal disease may also occur in renal transplant recipients and in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Mortality rates of 50 to 80% are reported
  • Factors implicated in pathogenesis are medically refractory hyperphosphatemia, high calcium-phosphate product, high PTH levels, use of warfarin, protein C and protein S deficiency and other causes of thrombophilia
  • Treatment options include sodium thiosulfate, phosphate binders, low calcium dialysate bath, bisphosphonates, calcimetics and parathyroidectomy
  • Because of potential of progression after subtotal parathyroidectomy total parathyroidectomy with trans cervical thymectomy is the preferred option
  • Role of urgent parathyroidectomy is controversial in management of calciphylaxis

REFERENCE: Sabiston 21st edition page no. 935

choices.text: Germline mutations and loss of heterozygosity in MEN1 gene of target tissues
Genotype phenotype correlation is more than 90%
MEN1 gene plays a role in non-hereditary endocrine tumors as well

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding MEN1 Genetics
questions.solution:
MEN1 Gene

  • MEN 1 is a hereditary cancer syndrome inherited in an autosomal dominant manner
  • The syndrome develops as a result of loss of heterozygosity in the MEN1 gene
  • The tumor suppressor gene encodes for proteins that regulate cell growth and proliferation that would normally participate in transcriptional regulation of DNA repair and cell signaling and mutations lead to a non-functioning protein

TWO HIT HYPOTHESIS

  • In the two hit hypothesis of tumor development mutation is inherited as a germline mutation thereby making the target tissues or organs susceptible to growth or neoplasms
  • The remaining normal or functional gene undergoes a somatic mutation or a second hit that result in Cancer development
  • this process is described as loss of heterozygosity

MEN1 genetic role

  • Additional role as a pro-oncogenic factor in mixer lineage leukemia by interacting with MLL-1 fusion protein to cause leukemia
  • Also been identified to have a role in its origin in estrogen receptor regulation and increased risk of developing breast cancer

Genotypes phenotype correlations

  • No genotype-phenotype correlations have been established for MEN1
  • There are however some data that identify mutations targeting the JunD interaction domain of the gene as being associated with an increased risk of death

REFERENCE: Sabiston 21st edition page no. 998 and 999

questions.text: Total thyroidectomy is the recommended treatment of choice in all the following cases of DTC except
questions.solution:
• This is again a Revised management to take note of
  • Total thyroidectomy was the traditionally recommended treatment for the majority of DTCs at least 1 cm.
  • However, ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy has become an acceptable alternative to total thyroidectomy for low-risk unilateral DTCs between 1 and 4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or evidence of metastatic disease, and it is the recommended surgical option for DTCs that are less than1 cm
  • Thus, total thyroidectomy is now the preferred evidence-based approach only for those DTCs at higher risk for recurrence and/or disease-specific mortality. Such scenarios include the following:
    • Tumour at least 4 cm
    • Gross extrathyroidal extension
    • Evidence of metastatic disease
    • Radiation-induced DTC
    • Familial non medullary thyroid cancer
    • Multifocal bilateral DTC

(-Also make an understanding of the recent addition to the topic,

Active Non-Operative Surveillance of PTC added in new Sabiston)

REFERENCE :Sabiston 21st edition page no. 903

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding RET Proto oncogene
questions.solution:
RET Gene-

  • Located on chromosome 10q11.2
  • Codes for membrane receptor with tyrosine kinase activity
  • RET protein is formed by and extracellular ligand binding domain and intracellular tyrosine kinase domain
  • They play role in cell growth and survival

Mutations

  • Mutations that result in development of MTC is missense mutation
  • Activating gain-of-function mutations

Hirschsprung disease in MEN2A

  • RET plays a role in development of neurons throughout the digestive tract

Inactivating mutations are associated with development of Hirschsprung disease in MEN2A disease not an activating mutation

REFERENCE: Sabiston 21st edition page number 1004

questions.text: Which enzyme's activity is increased in low insulin/glucagon level?
questions.solution:
Low insulin glucagon ratio can be understood/discussed in two ways, either as fasting/starvation state, or as low insulin level.

In either case, we have to know the action of insulin on the different pathways. Net effect of insulin on different pathways is as follows:

  • Increases:
    • Glycolysis
    • Glycogenesis
    • Lipogenesis
    • HMP shunt
    • Amino acid synthesis
    • Cholesterol Synthesis
  • Decreases:
    • Glycogenolysis
    • Lipolysis
    • Gluconeogenesis
    • Ketogenesis

The net action of hormone is on the enzymes. This means that the enzymes of the mentioned pathways are affected in a manner similar to the pathway.

Lastly, when the level of the hormone is decreased, the effects on the pathways will be reversed!

Of all the given options, option c (Glucose-6-phosphatase) is an enzyme of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, both of which would be upregulated when insulin level is low.

questions.text: Neonatal hypoglycaemia which does not response to counter regulatory hormone administration is diagnostic of -
questions.solution: In Cori’s disease, there is deficiency of the ‘debranching enzyme’, which is unaffected by the counter regulatory hormone, glucagon. Hence, fasting hypoglycemia in these conditions does not improve on administration of the hormone

questions.text: Identify the correct regulatory molecules:
questions.solution:
Insulin promotes glycogenesis (consumption of glucose), while glucagon promotes gluconeogenesis (proviuson/synthesis of glucose).

“A”, by inhibiting the inhibitor of glycogenesis (Glycogen Synthase), activates the process. Thus, it is insulin.

“B”, by activating the activator of glycogenolysis (Glycogen phosphorylase), strongly activates the process. Thus, it is glucagon.

questions.text: Glucose transporter in the myocytes, under the influence of insulin, is:

Group I hormones are:

  • Androgens

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Mineralocorticoids
  • Progestins
  • Retinoic Acid
  • Thyroid hormones (T3 and T4)

questions.text: A 37 yr old female with complaints of dry skin, fatigue, lethargy and weight gain was advised Thyroid profile and was diagnosed as hypothyroidism. Levothyroxine was started for this patient (at dose of 100mcg). All of the following drugs, if given for this patient, might decrease the absorption of levothyroxine EXCEPT?

A 54 yr old male patient, known case of HT/DM and IBD (Inflammatory bowel disease) was under treatment. After 5 months of therapy, he complained of pain in hip region while walking and on examination, there was restriction of abduction and internal rotation of thigh.
Plain radiograph of pelvis was taken.

Which of the following drugs the patient has taken previously led to the adverse effect?
questions.solution:
This is a case of steroid induced avascular necrosis of head of femur.

Mechanism:

Other drug induced avascular necrosis of bone:

  1. ACTH
  2. Arsenic compounds
  3. Ethanol
  4. NSAID (Indomethacin, Phenylbutazone, Diclofenac)

A 64 yr old woman was admitted to the hospital with complaints of difficulty in breathing. 4 years ago, she was diagnosed as hormone-positive Ca. Breast and underwent radical mastectomy and currently on Tamoxifen. CT thorax was taken.

As Tamoxifen was least responsive in this patient, what other drug can be given for treating her Ca. Breast?
questions.solution: This is a case of Tamoxifene resistant Ca. Breast. As the CT image shows multiple lung metastasis. Fulvestrant, A competitive estrogen receptor antagonist, is a better choice for treating her Ca. Breast.

OGTT showing 2 hr blood glucose ≥200 mg/dl

questions.text: All of the following are compatible with a diagnosis of pediatric diabetes except?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of DM in children using ADA – 2018 Criteria

Any 1 of the following, if present, is diagnostic

  1. Compatible clinical features + RBS ≥ 200mg/dl
  2. Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126mg/dl (8hrs fasting)
  3. Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT): If 2hr post test BG ≥ 200mg/dl
  4. HbA1C ≥6.5%

questions.text: Most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Abnormal thyroid gland development, also called Thyroid Dysgenesis is the cause of permanent CH in about 70% of cases.

  • Thyroid dysgenesis includes agenesis, hypoplasia, and ectopy (failure to descend normally into the neck).
  • It is almost always sporadic with no increased risk to subsequent siblings.
  • Rarely, thyroid dysgenesis is associated with a mutation in one of the transcription factors necessary for thyroid gland development (PAX8, FOXE1, NKX2.1, NKX2.5)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is a relatively less common cause

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match of clinical manifestation of adrenal insufficiency and the corresponding pathophysiologic mechanism?
questions.solution: Clinical manifestations of adrenal insufficiency and the corresponding pathophysiologic mechanisms

questions.text: Which of the following is the therapy of choice for prenatal management and prevention of virilization in suspected CAH?
questions.solution: Remember that for postnatal management of CAH, Hydrocortisone is preferred, while for prenatal management, Dexamethasone is preferred. According to Nelson 21st Ed, Mothers with pregnancies at risk for CAH may be given dexamethasone, a steroid that readily crosses the placenta, in an amount of 20 µg/kg pre-pregnancy maternal weight daily in 2 or 3 divided doses. This suppresses secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenal, including secretion of adrenal androgens. If started by 6 wk of gestation, it ameliorates virilization of the external genitals in affected females. Chorionic villus biopsy is then performed to determine the sex and genotype of the foetus; therapy is continued only if the foetus is an affected female.

questions.text: Which of the following are the causes of Type 1 DM?
All except one are the known viral infections contributing to diabetes Mellitus

A 41-year-old woman has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased urinary phosphate excretion. Injection of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Low blood [Ca2+] and high blood [phosphate] are consistent with hypoparathyroidism.

Lack of parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreases bone resorption, decreases renal reabsorption of Ca2+, and increases renal reabsorption of phosphate (causing lowurinary phosphate).

Because the patient responded to exogenous PTH with an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate(cAMP), the G protein coupling the PTH receptor to adenylate cyclase is apparently normal.

Consequently, pseudohypoparathyroidism is excluded.

Vitamin D intoxication would cause hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.

Vitamin D deficiency would cause hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia

choices.text: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) on the collecting duct

questions.text: Which of the following hormones act son its target tissues by a steroidhormone mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Thyroid hormone, an amine, acts on its target tissues by a steroid hormone mechanism, inducing the synthesis of new proteins.

The action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) on the collecting duct (V2 receptors) is mediated by cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), although the other action of

ADH (vascular smooth muscle, V1 receptors) is mediated by inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP3).

Parathyroid hormone (PTH), $1 agonists, and glucagon all act through cAMP mechanisms of action.

choices.text: antagonizes the action of prolactin on the breast
enhances the action of prolactin on the breast
inhibits prolactin release from the anterior pituitary
inhibits prolactin release from the hypothalamus

questions.text: A 38-year-old man who has galactorrhea is found to have a prolactinoma. His physician treats him with bromocriptine, which eliminates the galactorrhea. The basis for the therapeutic action of bromocriptine is that it
questions.solution:
Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist.

The secretion of prolactin by the anterior pituitary is tonically inhibited by the secretion of dopamine from the hypothalamus.

Thus, a dopamine agonist acts just like dopamine-t inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary.

questions.text:
Which of the following hormones?
originates in the anterior pituitary?
questions.solution:
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is secreted by the anterior pituitary.

Dopamine, growth hormone–releasing hormone (GHRH), somatostatin, and gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) all are secreted by the hypothalamus.

Oxytocin is secreted by the posterior pituitary.

Testosterone is secreted by the testes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complains of chronic constipation and anovulatory cycles for the last 6 months. Her vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema. USG neck examination shows diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations shows abnormally low serum levels of T3 and T4. Patient underwent thyroidectomy excised histopathological image of the specimen is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Let’s go option by option
  • a) This will show variable sized and dilated colloid filled spaces. (b) There will be presence of granuloma. (c) There is extensive infiltration of the parenchyma by a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells, which represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury. All of these features are suggestive of autoimmune (Hashimoto’s) thyroiditis. (d) There should be monotonous uniform infiltration by atypical lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman having angina pectoris, polyuria, and polydipsia for the past 3 years. On physical examination, she has a body mass index of 32. Laboratory studies show her HBA1c value of 14.4. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, but no ketonuria. The representative microscopic appearance of her kidneys is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism leading to the disease causing her findings?
questions.solution:
Let’s go option by option

  • (a) Chronic pancreatitis typically affects exocrine pancreatic function more than endocrine function. (b) Glucokinase gene mutations can lead to maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY), which is far less common than type 2 diabetes. (c) Nodular glomerulosclerosis, as shown in the figure, is a characteristic feature of renal involvement in diabetes mellitus and explains her proteinuria (which may progress to nephrotic syndrome). Peripheral insulin resistance is strongly linked to type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her history is classic for type 2 diabetes, as is the elevated haemoglobin A1c. Note that although premenopausal women are relatively protected from ischemic heart disease, diabetes tilts the balance and can promote development of coronary artery disease in younger women. (d) Although localized amyloid deposition in islets can be seen with type 2 diabetes, it is not linked to conditions such as multiple myeloma that involve additional organs with amyloid deposition.

choices.text: Cells typical shows zellballen pattern of arrangement
Cells varies from polygonal to spindle shaped cells
Cytoplasm of the cells is fine granular contains granules of catecholamine
The nuclei shows pleomorphism with prominent nucleol

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with history of hypertension since long time. These days he is having high blood pressure along with palpitations, headache, sweating and occasional tremor. Inspite of medication symptoms persist. He underwent whole body CT scan and well circumscribed lesion is identified in the adrenal medulla for which he underwent surgery. Histopathological examination (image shown below) of the lesion will show all of the findings, except:
questions.solution: • The histologic pattern in pheochromocytoma is quite variable. The tumors are composed of clusters of polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells or chief cells that are surrounded by supporting sustentacular cells, creating small nests or alveoli (zellballen) that are supplied by a rich vascular network. Uncommonly, the dominant cell type is a spindle or small cell; various patterns can be found in any one tumor. The cytoplasm has a finely granular appearance, best demonstrated with silver stains, due to the presence of granules containing catecholamines. The nuclei are usually round to ovoid, with a stippled “salt-andpepper” chromatin that is characteristic of neuroendocrine tumors. Electron microscopy reveals variable numbers of membrane-bound, electron-dense secretory granules

choices.text: High dose cosyntropin simulation test (250 μg cosyntropin)-simulated cortisol more than 18 μg/dL is a positive test
8 am Serum ACTH is increased in primary adrenal insufficiency
Prednisolone at the dose of 5 mg per day-Replacement dose

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding diagnosis and management of adrenal crisis
questions.solution:
Adrenal crisis

  • The primary understanding in diagnosis that

1)salivary or serum cortisol level is reduced and

2) ACTH levels increased primary adrenal insufficiency

3) ACTH levels are normal or low in secondary adrenal insufficiency

  • High dose cosyntropin simulation test (250 μg cosyntropin)- simulated cortisol less than 18 μg/dL is a positive test
  • The Algorithm in Fig 40.7 for diagnosis is given below

REFERENCE: Sabiston 21st edition page no. 973

choices.text: Negative plasma free metanephrine- needs 24-hour urine metanephrine to rule out pheochromocytoma, whereas for positive results- localisation by CT/MRI is done
Two 24 hours urine metanephrines are needed for biochemical confirmation in equivocal cases
0.3 mg Clonidine suppression test has 100% specificity
MIBG after CT or MRI is indicated if age<50 or on suggestion of multifocality

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding biochemical diagnosis of pheochromocytoma
questions.solution:
• The key understanding is in the concept of sensitivity and specificity

Screening/ 1st Step

  • Plasma free metanephrine testing is used as a principle screening tool
  • It excellent sensitivity of 99% and specificity of 89%
  • Being a onetime test more convenient than 24 hours urinary testing

2nd test

  • 24 hours urinary testing- if Plasma free metanephrine is positive
  • So negative tests- can be managed by observation or repeat testing if suspicion remains
  • Positive tests- can go for 24-hour urine metanephrine where they can be ruled out for observation/ proceeded for CT based on its positivity
  • The sequence and order of other investigations in Phaeochromocytoma is well explained in the algorithm Fig: 40.15

To conclude for the MCQ’s Option A- Positive Plasma-free metanephrines is a screening tool. i.e., It can rule out phaeochromocytoma but not confirm for further evaluation(localisation)

REFERENCE Sabiston 21st edition page no. 982
